required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Family-based eHealth Obesity Prevention Intervention for Hispanic Adolescents

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effects of a digital (web and mobile phone-based) program to improve physical activity levels and quality dietary intake among Hispanic parent-adolescent dyads.

primary_outcome.measure: Percent of parent-adolescent dyads retained and engaged at post-intervention (feasibility)
primary_outcome.description: We will calculate the % of enrolled parent-adolescent dyads retained from baseline to 2-months post-baseline (post-intervention). We will also calculate the % of parents and adolescents randomly assigned to the intervention condition who complete all 8 weekly sessions.

primary_outcome.measure: Percent of parent-adolescent dyads retained and engaged at follow-up (feasibility)
primary_outcome.description: We will calculate the % of enrolled parent-adolescent dyads retained from baseline to 8-months post-baseline (follow-up).

primary_outcome.measure: Mean participant ratings on weekly session content and post-intervention open-ended feedback (acceptability)
primary_outcome.description: Parents and adolescents randomly assigned to the intervention condition will rate their overall impression of each session using a 5-star rating scale; a subset of parent-adolescent dyads will also be interviewed at 2-months post-baseline to assess their acceptance of the intervention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in adolescent and parent physical activity
secondary_outcome.description: Adolescents will self-report their physical activity using the Youth Activity Profile. Parents will self-report their physical activity using the International Physical Activity Questionnaire.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in adolescent and parent dietary intake (i.e., fruits/vegetables, sugar)
secondary_outcome.description: Adolescents and parents will self-report their own dietary intake using the NHANES Dietary Screener Questionnaire. Cup equivalents of fruits and vegetables and teaspoon equivalents of added sugars will be calculated using a scoring algorithm developed by the National Cancer Institute.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in adolescent and parent sedentary behavior
secondary_outcome.description: Adolescents will self-report their sedentary behavior using the Youth Activity Profile. Parents will self-report their sitting time using a single item from the International Physical Activity Questionnaire

arm_group.description: Parent-adolescent dyads randomized to the Healthy Juntos intervention condition will access a program that includes didactic, behavioral, and positive parenting content from their smartphones for 8 weeks.
This group will receive a digital standard of care - a list of publicly available lifestyle apps and websites which they may access at their discretion.

intervention.description: Parent-adolescent dyads will log in to a secured website for a total of eight weeks. The intervention will be delivered primarily through smartphones and will include didactic content on healthy lifestyle behaviors (for parents/adolescents), family behavior change content for setting weekly goals and self-monitoring health behaviors (for parents/adolescents), and positive parenting content (for parents only), all of which were developed in accordance with participant feedback based on formative intervention development work. In addition, and to increase participant compliance/reduce attrition often observed in digital health interventions, human support ("supportive accountability") will be provided. Specifically, each family will be assigned a "coach" who will use video conferencing software or phone to engage in weekly 15-30 minute conversations with parents regarding their family's progress throughout the intervention period.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Public Health Sciences
